analysis.title: This Wedding Is Fucked
analysis.author: Erica Bardin & Susan Graham
analysis.logline: Two bitter exes wage war at a destination wedding, escalating their revenge schemes until they accidentally destroy the entire celebration and must work together to salvage their friends' marriage.

execution_independence.note: Concept works even with mediocre execution

concept.justification: Strong escalating premise with clear stakes - wedding destruction provides definitive endpoint
page_citations: Page 39: Jonathan pushed overboard by Melissa's sabotage
concept.weakness_identified: Premise feels familiar despite good execution

act_architecture.note: Clear three-act structure with time cards

momentum.note: Good escalation but some dead zones

structure.justification: Solid structure with effective time cards showing relationship deterioration and escalating pranks
page_citations: Page 1: 1165 days before wedding establishes timeline
structure.weakness_identified: Middle section has pacing issues with some unnecessary scenes

goal_clarity.note: Melissa wants to win the war against Jonathan

arc_credibility.note: Growth feels rushed in final act

protagonist.justification: Melissa has clear motivation but often reacts rather than initiates action
protagonist.weakness_identified: Dual protagonist structure dilutes individual character development

character_distinction.note: Nicole, Bradford, and Jasper have distinct voices

supporting_cast.justification: Strong supporting characters especially Nicole (controlling bride) and Jasper (scheming friend)
supporting_cast.weakness_identified: Some characters like Edward feel underdeveloped

dialogue.justification: Good character voices but dialogue often explains rather than reveals
dialogue.weakness_identified: Too much exposition and on-the-nose emotional moments

genre_execution.justification: Solid wedding comedy execution with good escalation of chaos
genre_execution.weakness_identified: Follows expected genre conventions without much innovation

originality.justification: Competent but familiar execution of well-worn premise
originality.weakness_identified: Feels derivative of existing wedding comedies

cultural_resonance.rationale: Wedding chaos and family dynamics translate well; universal themes of love and commitment

regional_casting_potential.rationale: Could cast Latin actors in lead roles; ensemble nature allows for diverse casting

theatrical_appeal.rationale: Broad comedy with visual gags works in theaters but not event-level

marketing_viability.rationale: Clear hook - wedding disaster comedy, easy to market

coproduction_potential.rationale: Would need location change but could work as co-production

comparable_success.note: Wedding comedies have mixed track record

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Act 1 ends around page 30 with relationship backstory complete; Act 2 escalates through wedding week; Act 3 begins with hotel fire around page 89
structure_analysis.pacing: Good setup and strong finale, but middle section drags with repetitive prank sequences

characters.protagonist: Melissa - photographer struggling with career vs. relationship goals, clear motivation but often reactive
characters.antagonist: Jonathan - successful entrepreneur, equally matched opponent in the war
supporting: Nicole - controlling bride with hidden pregnancy
Bradford - gay best friend helping Melissa
Nick - laid-back groom caught in middle

standout_scenes.scene: Shark attack fake-out leading to real shark
standout_scenes.why: Great escalation of physical comedy with real stakes
Satisfying climax that forces characters to confront consequences

comparable_films.title: Wedding Crashers
comparable_films.similarity: Wedding setting with romantic comedy elements

comparable_films.title: Bridesmaids
comparable_films.similarity: Female-driven wedding comedy with crude humor

target_audience.latam_audience_notes: Wedding and family themes resonate well in Latin America, but R-rating may limit theatrical audience

budget_tier.justification: Tropical location, ensemble cast, and fire/explosion sequences require solid budget

development_notes: Develop unique voice to differentiate from other wedding comedies
assessment.recommendation_rationale: Solid execution of familiar premise with good ensemble potential and clear marketing hook, but needs development to address pacing issues and add originality. CVS of 13 supports moderate commercial viability.

film_now_assessment.lightning_test: Opens with cute meet-cute rather than strong hook - doesn't grab immediately
film_now_assessment.career_risk_test: Would not stake career - too familiar and execution-dependent
film_now_assessment.legacy_potential: Unlikely to be remembered in 20 years

analysis.verdict_statement: This is a professionally written wedding comedy with solid structure and good ensemble potential, but it suffers from a derivative premise and familiar execution. The escalating chaos works well, but the script needs development to add originality and improve pacing before it can compete in the crowded comedy marketplace.
analysis.executive_summary: Competent wedding comedy about warring exes destroying a destination wedding. Good structure and ensemble cast potential, but derivative premise and pacing issues require development before greenlight consideration.
